Award.AwardTitle: Building a molecular foundation for tropical mycorrhizal biology: Sporocarp surveys of ectomycorrhizal fungal diversity of Southeast Asian dipterocarp forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Dipterocarpaceae is the most diverse and abundant tree family in the lowland tropical rain forests of Southeast Asia. There are more than 500 species and all depend on root-associated fungi called ectomycorrhizal (ECM) fungi to obtain soil nutrients. Ectomycorrhizal fungi have evolved intimate associations with particular groups of trees in forest communities across the world, but they are rare in most lowland tropical regions. However, the extent of ECM fungal diversity is unknown, thereby making tests of important evolutionary and ecological hypotheses difficult. While soil fungi predominantly exist in microscopic form, many fungi make macroscopic fruiting bodies during the sexual stage of their life cycle, enabling taxonomic identifications that can be coupled with molecular data. This project will make use of an existing collection of identified and curated fungi in Malaysia to begin building and DNA database for fungal diversity in dipterocarp forest. This effort will allow environmental samples of soils and roots to be linked to specific species of fungi. Also, fungal fruiting bodies from the dipterocarp forest will continue to be collected, identified, and sequenced at a greater intensity with efforts to identify host tree species of specific fungi.

Broader impacts for this project include the teaching and training of local Malaysian assistants and students. We will also provide an intensive training workshop for foreign and Malaysian researchers in the collection and identification of fungal sporocarps in the field. Digital images of sporocarps will be publicly available online. Since dipterocarps are also highly prized for timber and have experienced some the highest deforestation rates in the world, this research will be useful for implementing strategies for forest conservation and regeneration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Tropical rainforests are important storehouses of biodiversity and help regulate critical biosphere processes. While there is increasing awareness that microbial organisms influence the health of tropical trees, little is known about the ecology and taxonomy of microbial organisms themselves in tropical ecosystems. This represents a large gap in our knowledge of biodiversity on this planet and in our ability to understand the ecological processes that structure these critical ecosystems. Through NSF funding for this project, we address these knowledge gaps for a group of mutualistic soil microbes that positively influence plant health: ectomycorrhizal fungi. To increase knowledge of tropical ectomycorrhizal fungi and facilitate future research on these organisms we: (1) generated a large, publicly accessible DNA database of fungal sequences derived from fungal sporocarps and environmental samples, (2) linked these DNA sequences to vouchered specimens through a website, (3) trained local scientists and land managers on fungal identification & ecology in southeast Asia, and (4) applied next generation molecular tools to test an important ecological hypothesis about mycorrhizal fungi in tropical dipterocarp forests.  We collected nearly 300 fungal specimens from one of the most diverse tropical rainforests in the world (Lambir Hills National Park, Malaysia), extracted DNA, sequenced two common genetic barcodes used for fungal identification, and deposited these sequences in a publicly searchable database (National Center for Biotechnology’s Genbank). This research has expanded our knowledge of tropical microbial biodiversity and by generating DNA sequences that are associated with physical collections we can greatly facilitate other researchers by improving their ability to identify microbial organisms from environmental DNA. We also conducted a seedling transplant experiment that represents a critical first step in determining how interactions with ectomycorrhizal fungi influence tree recruitment and habitat specialization. In this study, we used next generation DNA sequencing, in conjunction with our sequence database, to test the hypothesis that tropical tree seedlings specialized on particular soil conditions do so through highly specialized interactions with ectomycorrhizal fungi. Our results reject this hypothesis as our DNA sequencing results showed that most seedlings associate with a wide range of ectomycorrhizal fungi.  Rejecting this hypothesis opens up exciting new questions about how plant-soil-microbe interactions structure tropical rainforests. Overall, through this project we were able to make important progress in cataloguing under-studied components of tropical biodiversity, generate resources that will facilitate future research, and shed important light on plant-microbe interactions.  

 

Broader Impacts:

Through this project we provided training for a number of US and international scientists. US students, and Malaysian scientists, students, and land managers, were trained through a 1-week workshop held at Pasoh National Park, Malaysia, that included both PIs as well as taxonomic experts from the US and Europe. Participants were introduced to diagnostic features of key fungal groups, the use of keys, proper field collection techniques, microscopy, and molecular ecology. In addition to expanding taxonomic knowledge, this workshop also helped foster international collaboration. In addition, US high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students participated in laboratory and field research activities associated with this project, contributing to scientific training and the development of an internationally capable US workforce. The molecular database we generated will also have broader impacts by creating information infrastructure that can facilitate research in a number of fields, including microbial ecology, ecosystems ecology, biogeography, and evolution. Finally, because ectomycorrhizal fungi play a key role in the health and regeneration of tropical forests in Southeast Asia, improvements to our knowledge of ectomycorrhizal ecology may contribute to the sustainable management of these economically important forests.
